senses.sense_definition: A political and economic theory advocating for a society where all property is publicly owned and each person works and is paid according to their abilities and needs.

examples.text: Many philosophers in the nineteenth century debated the merits of <w>communism</w> versus capitalism.
The students read a manifesto that outlined the core principles of <w>communism</w>.

senses.sense_definition: A system of government or social organization in which the state plans and controls the economy and a single, often authoritarian party holds power.

examples.text: Living under <w>communism</w> meant that the government controlled most aspects of daily life and production.
After the war, the country adopted <w>communism</w> and nationalized all major industries.

senses.sense_definition: Any policy, regulation, or political view perceived as too left-wing, controlling, or damaging to individual freedom, often used as an exaggeration.

examples.text: The opposition leader angrily claimed that the new tax plan was pure <w>communism</w>.
Critics argued that mandatory participation in the program amounted to <w>communism</w>.

senses.sense_definition: The state of sharing things in common or holding property collectively without private ownership.

examples.text: The small village operated on a principle of <w>communism</w> regarding food and shelter.
Early religious groups often practiced a form of <w>communism</w> where no one owned anything individually.

senses.sense_definition: The norm in the scientific community that scientific findings belong to the community as a whole and should be shared freely.

examples.text: The ideal of scientific <w>communism</w> suggests that researchers should not keep their results secret for profit.
Open access journals help support the principle of <w>communism</w> in academic research.
